key_points: Tropical Storm Ida caused at least 27 deaths in New Jersey and significant damage, including to Newark school buildings.
The storm led to catastrophic damage to Newark schools, including a fire, flooding, and the destruction of gym floors.
Initial estimates suggest at least $5 million in damage to Newark schools, a figure expected to rise.
The damage forced nearby school districts to consider delaying the start of the school year, but Newark schools opened as scheduled.
The opening was attributed to the hard work of maintenance crews, custodians, and other employees.
School board President Dawn Haynes praised the district employees for putting their needs aside for the children.
New Jersey remains under a state of emergency due to the damage from Tropical Storm Ida.
President Joe Biden visited New Jersey to tour the damage caused by the storm.
Some 33 Newark district buildings were flooded, affecting various facilities and parts of the schools.
The district has not disclosed which schools were damaged nor if they will receive state or federal disaster relief funds.
